metadata.title: Polymer supported palladium nanocrystals as efficient and recyclable catalyst for the reduction of nitroarenes to anilines under mild conditions in water
metadata.journal: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical

IMAGE-THUMBNAIL MOLCAA 9248 S1381-1169(14)00390-2 10.1016/j.molcata.2014.08.033 Elsevier B.V. Fig. 1 Recyclability of Pd-pol (1.75mol% of Pd) in the reduction of nitrobenzene in H2O in the presence of NaBH4 (NaBH4/PhNO2 molar ratio equal to 10) at room temperature (t =2h). Fig. 2 Transmission electron micrographs and associated size distribution (inset) of matrix polymer embedded Pd nanoparticles: (a) pristine Pd-pol (pre-catalyst); (b) Pd-pol recovered after the first run of the reduction of nitrobenzene in the presence of NaBH4; (c) Pd-pol recovered after the twelfth run of the reduction of nitrobenzene in the presence of NaBH4. Fig. 3 Transmission electron micrographs and associated size distribution (inset) of matrix polymer embedded Pd nanoparticles: (a) pristine Pd-pol (pre-catalyst); (b) Pd-pol recovered after the second run of the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene under 1atm H2 (in the absence of NaBH4). Scheme 1 Synthesis of Pd-pol. Scheme 2 Reduction of nitrobenzene catalyzed by Pd-pol. Scheme 3 Metal catalyzed production of H2 by NaBH4. Polymer supported palladium nanocrystals as efficient and recyclable catalyst for the reduction of nitroarenes to anilines under mild conditions in water Maria Michela Dell’Anna a ⁎ Simona Intini a Giuseppe Romanazzi a Antonino Rizzuti a Cristina Leonelli b Ferruccio Piccinni a Piero Mastrorilli a c a DICATECh, Politecnico di Bari, via Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy DICATECh, Politecnico di Bari via Orabona 4 Bari 70125 Italy b Dipartimento d’Ingegneria dei Materiali e dell’Ambiente, Università di Modena e Reggio Emilia, via Vignolese 905, 41125 Modena, Italy Dipartimento d’Ingegneria dei Materiali e dell’Ambiente, Università di Modena e Reggio Emilia via Vignolese 905 Modena 41125 Italy c Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Chimica dei Composti Organometallici (CNR-ICCOM), via Orabona 4, 70125 Bari, Italy Consiglio Nazionale delle Ricerche, Istituto di Chimica dei Composti Organometallici (CNR-ICCOM) via Orabona 4 Bari 70125 Italy ⁎ Corresponding author. Tel.: +39 080 5963695; fax: +39 080 5963611. Graphical abstract Polymer supported palladium nanoparticles (Pd-pol), generated in situ by Pd(II) reduction under reaction conditions, catalyze the hydrogenation of nitroarenes to anilines with high efficiency and recyclability, in water at room temperature in the presence of NaBH4. Polymer supported palladium nanoparticles, generated in situ by Pd(II) reduction under reaction conditions, catalyzed the hydrogenation of nitroarenes to anilines with high efficiency in water at room temperature in the presence of NaBH4. The protocol proved to be highly selective and generally favored the formation of the desired aniline as single product in high yields with short reaction times. TEM analyses revealed that the size distribution of the formed Pd nanocrystals was regulated by the reductant agent. In details, when 1atm H2 was used as the nitroarene reductant, the in situ generated polymer supported palladium nanoparticles were crystallites with diameters ranging from 6 to 10nm. On the contrary, when the reaction was carried out in the presence of NaBH4 in water under N2 or air, the formation of Pd nanocrystallites was observed as well, but this time they were smaller (mean size diameter ca. 3nm) and catalytically more active compared to the palladium nanoparticles formed under 1atm H2 in the absence of NaBH4. The catalyst displayed excellent recyclability over twelve cycles and no leaching of metal into solution occurred, which made the overall system eco-friendly and economic. Keywords Palladium nanoparticles Polymer supported catalyst Nitrobenzene reduction Water solvent 1 Introduction Aromatic amines are highly valuable chemical intermediates widely used in the manufacture of pharmaceuticals, polymers, pesticides, explosives, fibers, dyes and cosmetics [1]. Current industrial production of aniline involves the catalytic hydrogenation of nitrobenzene with copper, palladium or palladium-platinum supported on carbon or inorganic oxides, with the use of high pressure (up to 3MPa) and high temperature (up to 300°C). On the other hand, the traditional Béchamp reduction treats the nitroarene with stoichiometric amounts of Fe metal under acidic conditions, thus generating large amounts of waste. Another challenge that persists in these reactions is the unavoidable formation of harmful azo- and azoxyderivatives, which lower the yield into the desirable anilines. In order to overcome all these disadvantages, great efforts have been made by the scientific community with the aim to develop greener and cheaper hydrogenation catalytic systems with higher yields. Numerous protocols for the reduction of aromatic nitro compounds have been reported in the literature [2–7]. They include: 1) hydrogenation under H2 at various pressures promoted by various catalysts [8], such as Pt/C [9], Rh3Ni1 [10], Pd/C [11–13], Pd [14,15] and Rh [16] nanoparticles; 2) catalytic reduction in the presence of CO and H2O [17] and photocatalytic hydrogenation [18]; 3) catalytic transfer hydrogenation promoted, for example, by Cu [19], Pd [20], palladium/graphene [21], Au [22], Ru [23] or Fe3O4-Ni [24] nanoparticles with reducing agents other than molecular hydrogen [25,26], including hydrazine [27–32], silanes [33,34] and sodium borohydride [35–41]. In this last case, large use of Au based catalysts has been explored [42]. However, the major problems remains unsolved and the development of more effective, less toxic, and handle-convenient catalysts for this transformation is still highly desirable. With the aim to develop innovative catalytic processes that enable chemical transformations to be performed under mild and sustainable conditions with high efficiency, we decided to evaluate the catalytic activity of a polymer supported palladium catalyst (in the following Pd-pol) for the hydrogenation of nitroarenes in water. In order to obtain a material with a uniform distribution of the catalytically active sites, the catalyst was not synthetized by classical immobilization of palladium centers onto a pre-fabricated support, but it was prepared by co-polymerization of the metal-containing monomer [43] Pd(AAEMA)2 [AAEMA− =deprotonated form of 2-(acetoacetoxy)ethyl methacrylate] with suitable co-monomer (ethyl methacrylate) and cross-linker (ethylene glycol dimethacrylate) [44,45] (Scheme 1 ). Pd-pol was already found active and recyclable in several palladium promoted reactions [46–51]. As reported for nanoclustered palladium supported on methacrylate based resins [52], the reticular and macro porous polymeric support of Pd-pol is able to immobilize and stabilize palladium nanoparticles (formed under reaction conditions by reduction of the pristine Pd(II) anchored complex), suitable for the Suzuki cross coupling of arylhalides with arylboronic acids in water [53], for the aerobic selective oxidation of benzyl alcohols in water [54], for the selective hydrogenation of quinolines in aqueous medium under mild conditions [55], and for the reductive amination reaction under 1atm of H2 [50]. Furthermore, its good swellability in water renders Pd-pol an ideal potential catalyst for reactions carried out in aqueous solvent, since the migration of the reagents to the active sites would be not hampered by the solid support. Herein, we report on the high activity and recyclability of Pd-pol in promoting the nitrobenzenes hydrogenation into anilines in water in the presence of sodium borohydride, a well-known reducing agent with wide applications in organic synthesis for its ready availability, ease of handling, and low cost [56]. In addition, in this paper we demonstrate how the way in which the hydrogen is added to the reaction mixture (by reaction between NaBH4 and water or by external balloon) influences the nanostructure and consequently the activity of the in situ formed Pd nanoparticles. 2 Experimental 2.1 General considerations Tap water was de-ionized by ionic exchange resins (Millipore) before use. All other chemicals were purchased from commercial sources and used as received. Pd-pol was synthesized according to literature procedure [45]. Palladium content in Pd-pol was assessed after sample mineralization by atomic absorption spectrometry using a Perkin–Elmer 3110 instrument. The experimental error on the palladium percentage was ±0.3. Mineralization of Pd-pol prior to Pd analyses was carried by microwave irradiation with an ETHOS E-TOUCH Milestone applicator, after addition of HCl/HNO3 (3:1, v/v) solution (12mL) to each weighted sample. Microwave irradiation up to 1000W was used, the temperature being ramped from rt to 220°C in 10min and the sample being held at this temperature for 10min. After cooling to room temperature the digested Pd-pol was diluted to 1000mL before submitting to Graphite Furnace Atomic Absorption Spectrometric palladium determination. GC-MS data (EI, 70eV) were acquired on a HP 6890 instrument using a HP-5MS cross-linked 5% PH ME siloxane (30.0m×0.25mm×0.25μm) capillary column coupled with a mass spectrometer HP 5973. The products were identified by comparison of their GC–MS features with those of authentic samples. Reactions were monitored by GLC or by GC–MS analyses. GLC analysis of the products was performed using a HP 6890 instrument equipped with a FID detector and a HP-1 (Crosslinked Methyl Siloxane) capillary column (60.0m×0.25mm×1.0μm). Conversions and yields were calculated by GLC analysis by using biphenyl as internal standard, or by column chromatography using silica gel and n-hexane/ethyl acetate as the eluent. The microstructure of the polymeric matrix embedded Pd nanoparticles was determined by TEM observations at acceleration voltage of 200kV (Model JEM 2010, Jeol, Akishima Tokyo, Japan), equipped with X-ray energy dispersive spectroscopy (EDS). The samples were prepared by dispersing the powders in distilled water using an ultrasonic stirrer and then placing a drop of suspension on a copper grid covered with a transparent polymer film, followed by drying and carbon coating. The particle size distributions were obtained by TEM image analysis using the ImageJ software (freeware software: http://rsb.info.nih.gov/ij/). Each morphology observation was accompanied by EDS confirmation for the presence of Pd. 2.2 General experimental procedure for the reduction of nitroarenes catalyzed by Pd-pol using NaBH4 as reducing agent 1.0mmol of nitroarene, 37.2mg of Pd-pol (Pd%w =5.0, 0.0175mmol of Pd) and 10.0mmol of sodium borohydride were stirred under nitrogen at room temperature in 5mL of double deionized water for the appropriate amount of time, using a three-necked flask equipped by a gas bubbler in order to discharge the hydrogen excess produced during reaction. The progress of the reaction was monitored by GLC. After completion of the reaction, the reaction mixture was centrifuged to separate the catalyst. The solid residue was first washed with deionized water and then with acetone and diethyl ether to remove any traces of organic material. The filtrate containing the reaction mixture was extracted with ethyl acetate (3× 5mL) and then dried over anhydrous Na2SO4. The solvent was evaporated under reduced pressure to yield the crude product, which was then purified by column chromatography using silica gel and n-hexane/ethyl acetate as an eluent to afford the pure product. The products were characterized by GC–MS by comparison with authentic samples. For the assessment of the chromatographic yields, biphenyl (50.0mg) was used as the internal standard. 2.3 Recycling experiments The catalyst recovered by filtration was washed with water, acetone, and diethyl ether and dried under high vacuum. The recovered catalyst was thus weighed and reused for a new cycle employing appropriate amounts of organic substrate, sodium borohydride and solvent, assuming that the palladium content remained unchanged with the recycles. Iteration of this procedure was continued for twelve reuses of the catalyst. 2.4 Experimental procedure for the reduction of nitrobenzene catalyzed by Pd-pol in the presence of H2 (1atm) 1.0mmol of nitrobenzene and 37.2mg of Pd-pol (Pd%w =5.0, 0.0175mmol of Pd) were stirred under hydrogen (balloon) at room temperature in 5mL of double deionized water for the minimum time needed to reach reaction completion. Afterwards, the reaction mixture was centrifuged to separate the catalyst. The solid residue was first washed with deionized water and then with acetone and diethyl ether to remove any traces of organic material. The filtrate containing the reaction mixture was treated with ethyl acetate (3× 5mL) and the organic phase was analyzed by GLC in order to assess the corresponding yield using the internal standard (biphenyl) method. 3 Results and discussion To determine the optimum amount of sodium borohydride and water required for the reduction of nitroarenes, reduction studies were carried out with varying the amount of both NaBH4 and the solvent, using nitrobenzene as the representative substrate (Scheme 2 ). It can be seen from Table 1 that upon keeping the catalyst content constant, the time for completion of the reaction decreases on increasing the amount of borohydride reagent. In fact, following many literature procedures [37], we tried to use a molar quantity of NaBH4 fiftyfold compared to substrate, registering a minimum time to reach reaction completion equal to 30min (entry 1). However, the amount of borate salts produced was too high by an environmental point of view. To overcome this inconvenience, we carried out the reaction using a NaBH4/nitrobenzene molar ratio equal to 10 in 10mL (entry 2) and in 5mL (entry 3) of water, respectively. A quantitative yield into aniline was obtained in 2h in both cases, independently from the solvent amount, despite the fact that a higher concentration of NaBH4, increasing the pH value [57], might be responsible for the formation of stable azo-compounds [58], thus lowering the yield into the desired reduction product. As expected, by decreasing the amount of NaBH4 to 5.0mmol, the time reaction slightly increased to 3h (entry 4). No reaction occurred either in the absence of the sodium borohydride (entry 5) or palladium catalyst (entry 6). On the bases of the above results, we concluded that the optimum amounts of NaBH4 and water to be used for converting 1.0mmol of nitrobenzene into aniline in the presence of 37.2mg of Pd-pol (containing 5.0%w Pd) were the ones reported in entry 3. These experiments were important for determining the optimum reaction conditions to be used in the recycling tests and in the hydrogenation of various nitroarenes. Using the optimized reaction conditions, the activity and the scope of the catalyst was explored in the reduction of a variety of different nitroarenes (Table 2 ). The catalytic system was found to be very efficient regardless of the presence of electron-withdrawing and electron-donating substituents in the aromatic ring. Nitroarenes possessing electron-donating groups such as 2-, 3- and 4-nitrotoluene afforded excellent yields into the corresponding aniline in 3h (entries 1, 2 and 3). Also 3- and 4-methoxynitrobenzene were converted almost quantitatively into the corresponding anisidine in 5h (entries 4 and 5). Fluoro substituted nitrobenzene was selectively reduced to fluoroaniline in excellent yield and only trace of dehalogenated product was observed (entry 6), while in the case of bromo (entry 7) and chloro (entry 8) nitrobenzene the dehalogenation reaction was more important, thus suggesting future studies on the application of the present catalytic system for promoting the hydrodechlorination of polychloroarenes [59]. For compounds with two nitro groups, i.e. 1,4-dinitrobenzene, 1,3-dinitrobenzene and 1,2-dinitrobenzene (entries 9, 10 and 11), both nitro groups were reduced in 6h, though mono-amino products were also observed in minor quantities during the reaction time. Also 2,4-dinitrotoluene was slightly converted into the corresponding diamine in 5h (entry 12), showing no steric effects. These phenylenediamines are of interest, because extensively used in the manufactory of azo dyes [60,61]. The Pd-pol catalytic system was sensitive to the steric hindrance due to the presence of a substituent in ortho position respect to the nitro group only in the case of 2-nitrodiphenyl, which was converted to 2-aminodiphenyl with 50% of isolated yield (entry 13) in 96h. 2-Nitrophenol, which is known to be reduced through formation of nitrophenolate ion [62], was converted to 2-aminophenol in excellent yield in a short time (6h, entry 14). By employing the present catalytic system to a CO containing nitroarene, such as 4-nitrobenzaldehyde (entry 15), significant yield (10%) into 4-methylaniline was obtained, the other product being p-aminobenzyl alcohol, thus suggesting further studies aiming to applying the Pd-pol/NaBH4 protocol for the hydrodeoxygenation of pyrolysis oils [63]. Interestingly, by carrying out the nitrobenzene hydrogenation using H2 (1atm) as reducing agent instead of NaBH4, the reaction reached completion after 6h (entry 16), revealing that Pd-pol catalytic system was more active using NaBH4. The reusability studies of Pd-pol were carried out with nitrobenzene as the model substrate. After completion of the reaction (2h), the mixture was centrifuged to separate the solid catalyst from the reaction mixture. The catalyst was then thoroughly washed, dried under vacuum and successfully reused for eleven subsequent runs, where it showed the unaltered catalytic activity, giving the product in excellent yield (93–98%) for each cycle (Fig. 1 ). To verify whether the observed catalysis was truly heterogeneous or not, the reaction mixture was filtered after 30min reaction (40% conversion of nitrobenzene) and added of 10.0mmol NaBH4. Further stirring of the filtrate under the above reaction conditions did not yield any additional aniline product. Furthermore, the samples of Pd-pol recovered after 30min reaction and after the first cycle (2h), respectively, were mineralized and analyzed by atomic absorption spectrometry showing the same palladium content (within the experimental error) of the pre-catalyst. The same palladium amount was also found in the catalyst recovered at the end of the twelfth cycle of nitrobenzene hydrogenation. These results rule out any possible contribution of homogeneous catalysis by leached palladium species. This study was completed by the TEM characterization of Pd-pol before and after the first cycle and after the twelfth cycle, respectively, with the aim of ascertaining whether the reaction cycles affected the morphology and the dispersion of the palladium active species on the surface of the support. TEM images of pristine Pd-pol (pre-catalyst) and of the catalyst recovered after the first and the twelfth runs, are reported in Fig. 2a–c, respectively. The pristine catalyst was constituted mainly by polymer-bound Pd(II) species (not visible in the TEM micrographs), together with a low density of metallic Pd nanoparticle aggregates of 20–35nm in diameter. The primary particles ranging between 8 and 12nm in diameter (Fig. 2a) are attributed to the preparation of the pre-catalyst [64]: they presumably form during the thermal polymerization step of the catalyst synthetic procedure [45]. The TEM image of Pd-pol recovered after the first run (Fig. 2b) shows, besides the previously formed palladium nanoparticles, also a high number density of new Pd(0) nanoparticles, now ranging from 2 to 4nm, ascribable to the in situ NaBH4 reduction of Pd(II) supported polymer. On passing from the first to the twelfth cycle (Fig. 2c), the Pd(0) nanoparticles present a bimodal size distribution: the first one with a mean diameter centered at around 3nm and the second one centered at ca. 10–12nm. Remarkably, in Pd-pol recovered after the twelfth run, the percent amount of the smallest palladium nanoparticles (with diameter equal to ca. 3nm) still remained high, while the presence of larger nanoparticles (10–12nm diameter) might indicate the growth (no agglomeration) of the smallest Pd(0) nanoparticles with the re-cycles. However, the level of nanoparticle growth that we do observe in the present work is not enough to cause a significant decrease in the catalytic activity. As shown in the insets of Fig. 2b and c, Pd(0) nanoparticles formed by NaBH4 reduction are single crystallites, showing lattice images with an interplanar spacing of 0.22nm ascribable to metallic Pd {111} plane [65]. As expected, the formation of catalytically active palladium nanoparticles, stabilized by the insoluble matrix of Pd-pol, was observed also when the catalyst was employed for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene in water under 1atm H2, in the absence of NaBH4 (Fig. 3b). These nanoparticles, generated by hydrogen reduction, had a different size distribution compared to those formed using NaBH4 as reducing agent and reported in Fig. 2b. In fact, it is known that the nature of the reducing agent can strongly influence the nanostructure and the size distribution of the formed metal nanoclusters [65,66]. In the pre-catalyst batch (Fig. 3a) used for the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene under 1atm H2 (in the absence of NaBH4), Pd(0) nanoparticles exhibited diameter sizes ranging from 14 to 16nm and the same nanostructured morphology observed in the pristine catalyst (Fig. 2a) used for the nitrobenzene reduction in the presence of NaBH4. Although the nanoparticles diameter size distributions observed in the two pre-catalyst batches are slightly different (Figs. 2a and 3a), both the Pd-pol batches exhibited the same catalytic activity, when used as promoter for the reduction of nitrobenzene (1.0mmol) in water (5mL) in the presence of 10.0mmol NaBH4, thus demonstrating that the thermal reduction occurred during the synthetic procedure did not significantly affect the catalyst properties. In the TEM image of Pd-pol recovered after the second run of the hydrogenation of nitrobenzene under 1atm H2 (in the absence of NaBH4, Fig. 3b) the formation of new primary Pd(0) nanoparticles with diameter sizes ranging from 6 to 10nm was observed. These Pd nanoparticles were crystallites with an interplanar spacing of 0.22nm ascribable again to Pd metallic {111} plane [65]. The different nanoparticle diameter distributions observed in the two Pd-pol samples, the first one reduced by NaBH4 and the second one reduced by 1atm H2 (balloon), were presumably responsible for the different catalytic activities showed by the two resins. NaBH4 acts as a reducing agent of the metal in a dual way, by providing hydrides and by generating hydrogen gas. In fact, the hydrides from sodium borohydride can displace negatively charged ligands bound to Pd(II) (the β-ketoesterato moieties in the case of Pd-pol, Scheme 1), generating Pd-hydrides directly, which upon β-hydride elimination of H2, give the reduced metal. In addition, the in situ formed H2 in water (Scheme 3 ) in the closeness of Pd(II) can reduce it to Pd(0) with formation of small size metal nanoparticles. On the contrary, in the case of Pd-pol stirred under 1atm H2 (balloon), the reduction occurs only by gas hydrogen, which has to be transported to the liquid phase and then to the Pd-pol structure. Since the metal reduction proceeds more slowly compared to one obtained in the presence of NaBH4, there is enough time to form larger palladium crystallites. However, in both Pd-pol promoted nitrobenzene reductions (the first one in the presence of NaBH4 and the other one under 1atm H2), high amount of nitrosobenzene was detected during reaction, suggesting that the substrate was first hydrogenated to nitrosobenzene. By using NaBH4 in water in the presence of Pd-pol, the formation of large amount of hydrogen bubbles was observed in the reaction mixture, according to the well-known metal catalyzed transformation [67] reported in Scheme 3. Mechanistically the palladium catalyzed reduction of nitroarenes (I) in the presence of hydrogen (external or in situ generated) may go through the formation of hydroxylamine (III) and then aniline (IV) (direct route) as well as through the formation of diazoarene (VI) (condensation route) [68] (Scheme 4 ). The direct route is the preferred pathway for the hydrogenation of aromatic nitro compounds promoted by Pd and Au based catalysts [25,37,69], although alternative mechanistic ways have been proposed for Pd/C catalytic systems [70,71]. The formation of the intermediates reported in Scheme 4 was often observed with other reducing systems [72] and in some cases it was possible to obtain selectively the azo-coupling compounds [73]. During the reduction with NaBH4/Pd-pol system, some of the diazo-intermediates were detected (TLC and/or GLC analysis) only in trace amounts, while the nitroso compound (II) was the only intermediate always present in major quantity. Its concentration decreased with time to yield more of the desired product, once the substrate finished. The absence of arylhydroxylamine (III) in the reaction mixture could signify that its reduction was faster compared to that of the nitrosoarene hydrogenation. An unexpected huge amount of diazobenzene (VI) was detected in the mother liquor filtrated at 30% substrate conversion and left under stirring for three more hours after addition of excess NaBH4. In this case, in the filtrate removed of the supported catalyst, the coupling between nitroso benzene (II) and aniline (IV) (to give diazobenzene, VI) occurred (Scheme 4), because the nitrosobenzene was not converted into hydroxylamine benzene (III) in the absence of Pd-pol. These results suggested that the Pd-pol reducing system went preferentially through the formation of hydroxylamine and then aniline (direct route). A major strength of this reaction protocol is its recyclability and its ability to perform the reduction in neat water, which is not trivial when using water insoluble substrates. By comparing the Pd-pol system catalytic results with those obtained with commercial available Pd/C catalyst [2], it is apparent that in the latter case the use of alcohol as the solvent (in which Pd/C is even pyrophoric) cannot be avoided in order to obtain high yields. On the other hand, certain Au based catalysts are more selective than Pd-pol, tolerating substrates that contain a wide range of functional groups, although needing huge amount of NaBH4 [37]. 4 Conclusions In conclusion, the polymer supported palladium catalyst Pd-pol efficiently promoted the reduction of aromatic nitroarenes in water at ambient temperature in the presence of NaBH4. No other additives were needed for the reaction. The catalyst could be recovered at the end of the reaction and re-cycled for at least twelve times with the same activity and selectivity. TEM analyses showed that the active species were in situ formed Pd nanoparticles with average diameter of 3nm, that did not aggregate with the re-uses and did not leach out in solution during reaction. Due to their morphology and size, these Pd nanoparticles were found to be considerably more active than those obtained by reduction of Pd-pol pre-catalyst under 1atm H2. All these results made the Pd-pol recyclable heterogeneous catalytic system suitable and environmentally sustainable for the reduction of aromatic nitroarenes. coredata.dc:description: Polymer supported palladium nanoparticles, generated in situ by Pd(II) reduction under reaction conditions, catalyzed the hydrogenation of nitroarenes to anilines with high efficiency in water at room temperature in the presence of NaBH4. The protocol proved to be highly selective and generally favored the formation of the desired aniline as single product in high yields with short reaction times. TEM analyses revealed that the size distribution of the formed Pd nanocrystals was regulated by the reductant agent. In details, when 1atm H2 was used as the nitroarene reductant, the in situ generated polymer supported palladium nanoparticles were crystallites with diameters ranging from 6 to 10nm. On the contrary, when the reaction was carried out in the presence of NaBH4 in water under N2 or air, the formation of Pd nanocrystallites was observed as well, but this time they were smaller (mean size diameter ca. 3nm) and catalytically more active compared to the palladium nanoparticles formed under 1atm H2 in the absence of NaBH4. The catalyst displayed excellent recyclability over twelve cycles and no leaching of metal into solution occurred, which made the overall system eco-friendly and economic.
coredata.dc:title: Polymer supported palladium nanocrystals as efficient and recyclable catalyst for the reduction of nitroarenes to anilines under mild conditions in water

coredata.prism:publicationName: Journal of Molecular Catalysis A: Chemical
